content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the vertical distance \(d_0\), in mm, between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench
The diagram is drawn \(1 / 10^{\text{th}}\) actual size. Calculate the actual distance \(D_0\), in mm, between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench
A student hangs a 1.0N load on the spring. He measures and records the distance \(D\) between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench, and the value of the load \(L\)
He repeats the procedure using loads of 2.0N, 3.0N, 4.0N and 5.0N. The distance readings are shown in Table 1.1
Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring, for each set of readings, using the equation \(e = (D_0 - D)\). Record the values of \(L\) and \(e\) in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(e / \text{mm}\) (y-axis) against \(L / \text{N}\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
When making measurements, the student is careful to avoid a line-of-sight error
Suggest one other precaution that the student should take when measuring the distance \(D\) between the bottom of the spring and the surface of the bench
[Total: 11]
The IGCSE class is investigating the stretching of a spring
Fig. 1.1 shows the experimental set up
Record the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.2
Complete the column headings in the table
State whether the rate of cooling is significantly faster, slower, or about the same when using the larger volume of hot water. Justify your answer by reference to the readings
statement
justification
A student pours \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker. She measures the temperature the water at time \(t = 0\) and records it in a table
She starts a stopclock and records the temperature of the water at 30s intervals until she has a total of six values up to time \(t = 150s\). The readings are shown in Table 2.1
She repeats the procedure, using \(250 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
If this experiment were to be repeated in order to check the results, it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two such conditions that should be controlled
The IGCSE class is investigating the rate of cooling of water under different conditions
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.2
Draw a circuit diagram of the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1, using standard symbols
Calculate \(R_{\mathrm{A}}\), the combined resistance of lamps \(\mathbf{L}\) , \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\), using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{A}}}{I_{\mathrm{A}}}\)
On Fig. 3.2, draw a pointer showing the current \(I_{\mathrm{A}} = 0.65\mathrm{A}\)
A student records the current \(I_{\mathrm{A}}\), the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{L}\) and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{M}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{M}\)
The student rearranges the circuit so that the three lamps are in series with each other. He records the potential difference across each lamp in turn
Calculate the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) across the three lamps using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{\mathrm{L}} + V_{\mathrm{M}} + V_{\mathrm{N}}\)
A student suggests that \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) should be equal to \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\)
State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
[Total: 8]
The IGCSE class is investigating the potential differences across circuit components
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used
On Fig. 4.1, draw a normal at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{E}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\) to the left of the normal and at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal.
A student places the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace she draws the outline of the block ABCD
On Fig. 4.1, mark suitable positions for the pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) and label this point \(\mathbf{G}\)
Draw the line \(\mathbf{GE}\)

The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on the line \(\mathbf{FE}\), placing one pin close to \(\mathbf{E}\). She observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other. She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
Measure and record the angle of refraction \(r\) between the line \(\mathbf{GE}\) and the normal
Calculate the ratio \(\frac{i}{r}\)
Calculate the ratio \(\frac{i}{r}\)
A student suggests that the ratio \(\frac{i}{r}\) should be a constant
State and explain briefly whether your results support this suggestion
[Total: 8]
The student repeats the procedure but with the angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\). The angle of refraction \(r = 26^{\circ}\)
The IGCSE class is investigating the refraction of light passing through a transparent
The apparatus and ray-trace sheet are shown in Fig. 4.1
The IGCSE class has a range of apparatus available. Here is a list of some apparatus
ammeter
barometer
beaker
electronic balance
manometer
measuring cylinder
metre rule
newtonmeter (spring balance)
stopwatch
tape measure
thermometer
voltmeter
Complete Table 5.1 by inserting the name of one piece of apparatus from the list that is the most suitable for measuring each quantity described

table.html:
quantity to be measuredmost suitable apparatus
volume of water
a distance of about 50 m
the force required to lift a laboratory stool
the mass of a coin
the pressure of the laboratory gas supply

content.text: Explain briefly how you would avoid a parallax (line-of-sight) error when using the metre rule
State a precaution that you would take to ensure that the image is well focused
[Total: 7]
The IGCSE class is carrying out a lens experiment. This involves using an illuminated object, a screen and a lens
Firstly, the distance between the illuminated object and the lens is measured with a metre rule. Next, a clearly focused image is obtained on the screen
